results.title: Phenakistiscope disc (Politeness)
results.brief_description: The phenakistoscope is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc is fitted to the device and when seen through the slots, comes to life.
results.description:
This is one of the first devices to create the illusion of motion from still images. A stroboscopic cardboard disc featuring a sequence of slightly different pictures is mounted on a handle. Around the disc’s rim, above the images, are equally spaced slots. Nothing magical happens when you spin the disc, but the images flicker to life when you peer through the slots at the disc’s reflection in a mirror.

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.
description_for_label:

Invented almost simultaneously in 1832 by Joseph Plateau in Brussels and Simon von Stampfer in Berlin, the phenakistoscope was an important predecessor of the zoetrope, and its infinitely looping animation is reminiscent of today’s GIFs.

results.title: Magic lantern slides
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth. When photography arrived in the 1840s, photos started appearing on lantern slides.

constellations_primary.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_primary.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.description:
Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

In the 1820s, copperplate printing processes allowed an image to be stamped on glass. This led to mass slide production from the mid-1800s to the 1920s – particularly of toy slides, which were printed with decals and bordered with colourful edges to protect children’s hands.

The arrival of photography in the 1840s advanced things: photos printed on glass brought real-life scenes to life. But technology didn’t diminish the craftsmanship of lanternists, who still retouched worn slides by hand.
description_for_label:
Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

In the 1820s, copperplate printing processes allowed an image to be stamped on glass. This led to mass slide production from the mid-1800s to the 1920s – particularly of toy slides, which were printed with decals and bordered with colourful edges to protect children’s hands.

The arrival of photography in the 1840s advanced things: photos printed on glass brought real-life scenes to life. But technology didn’t diminish the craftsmanship of lanternists, who still retouched worn slides by hand.

results.title: Silent Number
results.creator_credit: Hugh Burton, Jamie Blanks and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Babysitter Nicole is subjected to a horrific night of phone calls from a guy called Matt, claiming to be beaten by his father and imprisoned in a cold place. When a bloodied man comes to the door claiming that he and his wife have been in an accident, she decides it is time to call the police. Cast includes Bronwyn Jones and John Brumpton.
